title: Views and more views
text: We weren’t up for the entire length of the trip so we only did the 1 mile portion to Imerovigli. This well trodden stone path is on the caldera edge so you have views forward towards Oia and back to Fira almost the entire way. It’s crowded when the ships come in but once you’re away from the shops you duck the crowds.

title: Lodging at its finest
text:
When we arrived for our 3 day visit the owner met us at the door and insisted on carrying our bags up the stairs. I was embarrassed as she was over 60, but before I could object up went the bags.
This was but a portend for the incredible hospitality she provided through our stay. Our room was on the top floor with a very large totally private outdoor balcony with a view up to the castle. Room was spotless. Breakfast was made to order. The owner makes fresh spanakopita daily. The location is perfect, in old town but a bit away from the hustle.
I’ve travelled widely but this may be the most pleasant proprietor and inn I’ve ever stayed at. Couldn’t recommend it more highly.

title: Best quick bite
text: If you’re looking for an under 5 Euro quick bite this is the place to go. It is a hole in the wall with about 5 stools. When I went For a take out they patiently explained the souvlaki or gyro options. Delicious.

title: What a setting!
text:
I didn’t realize that the setting was so spectacular. Be aware that to reach the stadium you’ll be walking uphill on well graded paths and steps. Bring water and sensible shoes or sneakers.
Also, you’ll appreciate it more if you do a little reading beforehand so you understand the background.

title: Must do
text: Even if you’re not a museum goer this is a must do. But be sure to bring a guidebook or listen to the Rick Steves audio guide, which is free. It provides an excellent overview in chronological order of the impressive antiquity.

title: Loved it
text: Walk in the footsteps of Aristotle, Plato and Pericles. But read up or listen to rick steves' excellent audio guide so you know what you’re looking at.

title: Must see
text: Even if you’re not a Greek history buff this is a must see. We bought a small group tour from Athens Walking Tours which was worthwhile. Group was about 15 and we walked up the hill with the guide. Tour lasted about 2 hours. Be sure to wear good footwear as the trek up is very slippery and rocky.

title: A highlight of Miami Beach
text: If you enjoy walking then check this out. It is a paved wide trail that follows the ocean side of Miami Beach. You can hop off it any time and walk on the sand or duck into a hotel or retract. It is nicely designed and changes from pavement to wood.

title: Highlight of our Havana trip!
text:
We booked this tour for 6 of us three months before we arrived based on reviews we read on Trip Advisor.
All our emails were promptly answered and the operator told us we didn't have to pay until the tour was over. We booked a Havana Highlights tour for 6 hours. The private tour cost was 240CUC for the 6 of us. If you didn't want a private tour the cost would be less. Finding the guide was easy as the meeting spot was ten minute walk from the ship terminal.
Our English speaking guide, Xuri, was tremendous! I would highly recommend her. She was university educated and very personable and spoke great English. From 10AM to 12:30 we walked around old Havana and she answered all our questions. We then loaded into a comfortable van (that seated the 6 of us, our guide and the driver.) They brought us to a very nice restaurant for lunch. The lunch was great with Cuban delicacies, but the patrons were either rich Cubans or other tourists.
After lunch we were driven around the area to see places we couldn't walk to. The tour ended about 4PM.
FerTours was great and I have nothing but superlatives for this company and their guide.

title: A highlight of our Havana trip
text:
Let's remember that the US sponsored an invasion of Cuba in the early 1960's. It's called the Bay of Pigs. The invasion was poorly planned and failed.
So this museum is the Cuban government's celebration of Castro's rise to power. It is full of military equipment and portray's Castro and Che Guevara as full fledged Cuban heroes. If you are interested in history and the Cuban's view of their revolution then this is a must-see. Whether you are a fan of the gov't or not it is worth a visit to get a feel for how things are there.
place: Museum of the Revolution (Museo de la Revolucion)

title: Fascinating area
text: We were on a cruise that docked in Cienfuegos. We walked from the ship to this square. Many of the buildings have a Spanish Colonial feel to them and are attractive to see. There is also a gazebo and green space to sit and people watch. There are carts in the vicinity selling souvenirs.

title: Great alternative to the beach
text:
We thoroughly enjoyed our trip to these ruins. If you go don't just walk around - hire a guide. Our guide cost about $10 total for the 4 of us. He was well educated, spoke flawless English and was charming and full of historical info about the ruins and the Mayan people.
Younger children wouldn't enjoy it. But if you enjoy history and want to spend a couple hours learning about the indigenous people of the area take a taxi to the ruins and grab a guide.

title: Worth a visit!
text: Although i wasn't in the market for a set of pipes I had read this this location is one of the most famous shops of its kind in Scotland so I dropped in. The owner was in his workshop and came out to talk to us and give us a great education about bagpipes, Enjoyed the visit!

title: Favorite Castle
text: We visited about 5 castles during our tour of Scotland. This was my favorite. It is in ruins. But its majestic location makes it a must see.

title: Quite a sight!
text: Although I am not a Harry Potter fan I still very much enjoyed the visit to the iconic location. It is worthwhile to take the short hike to the viaduct for great views.

title: Worth a stop
text: We drove the Trotternish Peninsula and this was one of the highlight stops. When we arrived there was a bagpiper in full regalia playing tunes.

title: Worth a visit!
text: I was not sure what this was all about until I visited. It is hard to explain. Just imagine lots of faeries and hobbits living somewhere and then abandoning it.

title: Very picturesque
text: Didn't pay to go inside but I still enjoyed walking around and taking pictures. Great history here and there is also a cafeteria.

title: If you're a golfer you'll enjoy this
text: I'm not a golfer but I appreciate the history of the bridge and the course. If you are lucky you can run out between golfers and take your picture on it.

title: Amazing place
text: Even if you are not a person who appreciates gardens of this scale you will enjoy walking around and admiring the various sights to be found here.

title: A must do in Edinburgh
text: It is a very nice walk, not too tough for a average fit person. The views at the top are worthwhile.

title: Best view of castle
text: If you are are visiting the two castles in the area you shouldn't miss this. It has a tremendous view of Neuschwanstein. Just try and avoid visiting when busloads of tourists are there.

title: Hike around the lake for great views
text: While the wives visited the castle the husbands opted for a hike around Lake Hopfensee. The hike is totally flat and the footing is either a dirt path or pavement. Throughout the 4 mile hike around the lake you are rewarded with great views of the nearby mountains.

title: Beautiful inn, but one important caveat
text: I stayed at the Hampton Terrace recently. The inn is beautiful. The grounds, the buildings, the cleanliness, the furnishings, the breakfast and the pool are all first rate. However, if I were to stay again I would never stay in the carriage house. When an upstairs guest showers or merely turns on the water the sounds are near-deafening. To compare these sounds to a jet engine taking off is admittedly an exaggeration, but not by much. To spend $300+/night and endure these noises unfortunately reduces my rating.

title: The views make it worth it
text: We visited in May shortly after the road opened. As it was a warm day we were able to sit outside in comfort. There was still 6" on snow on the ground. The food is overpriced as you'd expect, but we enjoyed a beer and the views.

title: Must do
text: We stopped here and parked because it is from this location where you hop on the bus to go up to Eagle's Nest. We hadn't been planning to visit the Documentation Center. We decided to go in and glad we did. The exhibits are sobering but presented in a manner that made the visit unforgettable. My advice is not to go up to Eagle's Nest until you've visited this location.

title: Enjoyed the Fortress
text: We took the funicular up to the fortress and spent an hour walking around. Most of the exhibits have English signage. If you like old fortresses you'll like this. But I wouldn't rate it a must-see.

title: A Munich Highlight
text: A very large park and easy to get to. Whether you want to stroll, visit a beer garden or see the river surfers - you can do it all here.

title: Great place to "feel" Munich
text: We found ourselves walking through the market several times during our visit to Munch. We had lunch here and enjoyed sitting and watching the locals.

title: Enjoyed this!!
text: You can walk 360 degrees atop the wall around the city. Great idea for families or folks who enjoy walking.

title: Great to look at
text: This is certainly an amazing sight. It conjures up all kids of Disney fantasies. Personally, I enjoyed gazing at it from Mary Bridge as well as several other vantage points. I wasn't so fascinated with the inside tour.

title: Enjoyed the tour
text: While not as impressive as nearby Neuschwanstein to look at, this castle has a more interesting tour, in my opinion. I believe the castle is still in the family. Hence , the furnishings are original.

title: Must do
text: It's difficult to explain the feeling you have after visiting here. It's confusing - a mixture of deep sadness and incredulousness over how it happened. Unfortunately, my visit was adversely impacted by gypsies who badgered me while I was walking through the aisles of the memorial.
place: The Holocaust Memorial - Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe

title: Impressive, but disappointing
text: This was on my list of top things to do in Oslo. I went there on a sunny September afternoon and it was almost deserted. I had hoped to see folk dances, native costumes and demonstrations. Instead, we were but two of about 20 people in the entire park and there were no programs whatsoever. I realize we were there off season but I had hoped for more. The buildings and the property were impressive. But to walk around with no guidance and look at empty old buildings was a disappointment to me.

title: Forest only a short Metro ride a way!
text: If y you're in Oslo and want to get away from it all then take the Frognerseteren line to the end and you literally walk off the tram to a mix of hiking trails. The ride to the end is about 30 minutes. Depending on the season you can hike, bike or ski. There are short and long trails available. The hit vary in difficulty but the trails close to the tram are easy. Along the way you will pass by by the Holmenkollen stop where the world famous ski jump is located where you can ride up to the top and look down at Oslo.

title: Gotta do this when in Oslo
text: While this isn't a jaw-dropping location that will give you goosebumps, not do you need to be an art connoisseur, it is so unique that you need to do this when in Oslo. They park itself is large and you can walk or bike around. The centerpiece, of course, are Vigeland's sculptures. We took a tram to the park and spent about 1-2 hours strolling around. The visit could easily be extended with a picnic or a guided walk. We didn't go inside the museum. The park can't help but generate a smile as you walk by all the peeps that he sculpted.

title: Hey, you're in Norway, you gotta see a viking ship!
text: We took the 20 minute ferry over to the "island" (its really a peninsula) to visit this, the Folk and the Kon-Tiki museums. Since we had an Oslo Pass everything was free. We must have gotten off at the incorrect stop as we had a half-mile walk to the location. The museum deign is very clean and straightforward. The remains of three ships are on display and you can walk right up to them. It is pretty amazing when you realize how old they are and what they've been through.

title: Visiting the Bygdoy was a no-brainer for us
text: We visited the Viking, Kon-Tiki and Folk Museums while out on the Peninsula. Get an Oslo Pass and admission and transportation will be free. We enjoyed all three and didn't get to the Polar Explorers museum which is located nearby. A visit to all three prove you a great context tot Norwegian traditions and history.

title: A Fascinating Story
text: Many school children have read about Thor Heyerdahl's incredible adventures and fascinating theories. To see the actual ships and watch the movies were a thrill for me. To think his crew braved a 101 day 4300 mile journey in a balsa wood craft is pretty amazing.

title: A Must-Do 5 Star attraction
text: This was one of Norwegian highlights. It is located nearby Geiranger. We were driving from Loen and took our car to the top although there are many bus excursions available from nearby Geiranger. The road up is switchback city and the views down to the fjord get better with each passing turn. There is a restaurant, gift shop and WC's at the top. The reason you go there is the viewpoint down to Geirangerfjord. The view is otherworldly. Hopefully, you'll have clear weather up there as we did.

title: Unbelievable!!
text: I don't think I can find the words to describe the beauty of the fjord. Take a boat trip, do some kayaking and find a place to sit in awe of it.

title: Very nice, but not particularly nicer than about 100 other Norwegian waterfalls!
text: The Geiranger Fjord is tremendous. But this waterfall is no more spectacular than many others we saw. We kayaked to it in September. It was likely less dramatic in this month, but I wouldn't go our of my way to see this one.

title: A Must-Do 5 Star attraction
text:
The view from the Lookout is an absolute 5 star attraction. Don't go to Flam without going up there.

We were in Flam after having arrived on the train. We wanted to see the viewpoint and another area attraction, the Borgund Stave Church and only have a half day. We hired a guide and taxi from Gudvangen Taxi and our driver, Roger, made the trip to both locations one of our Norway highlights.

title: One of my Norway Highlights
text: We hired a driver (Roger from Gudvangen Taxi) to bring us up to the Stegastein Lookout (also Borgund Stave Church). The road was spectacular. It is stark and moonlike with views the entire way. The Stegastein Lookout is the highlight but eh entire drive is well worth it.

title: The setting is surreal
text: I'd heard about Stave Churches but wasn't sure what to expect. I'm glad to have chosen this one to visit. The setting is gorgeous. The adjoining cemetery is even worth strolling through. The inside is less interesting. It's a view I'll long remember. By the way, if you are visiting from Flam and don't have a car consider hiring Gudvangen taxi whose guide, Roger, made the trip very interesting for us.

title: The 5 star rating tells it all
text: We booked this ourselves directly from NSB as a trip from Oslo>Myrdal>Flam. Don't need a travel agent of third party to do it. The trip itself is spectacular. We had clear weather and I would have enjoyed it just as much with snow or even rain. The trains are quaint and add to the charm. There are no saved seats so you board and elect a seat. In September it isn't crowded. I can imagine that in high season it would be hectic. I think sitting on the left side si marginally more scenic.

title: 5 stars is all you need to know!
text: We visited several fjords in Norway. In my judgment nothing beats the Naeroyfjord. To sit on a quiet slow moving ship is the way to go, in my opinion. There are fast boat alternatives,, but we weren't looking for an adrenaline rush.

title: A bit touristy
text: Pretty postcard picture, but take time to learn the history. we visited the Hanseatic Museum which increased our appreciation and enjoyment of the area.

title: One of the nicest hotels I've stated in
text: The hotel is situated above the town so it is a half hour walk to the water if that is important to you. But the upside is the views from the hotel. The pool and spa are world class. We drove to the hotel after having visited Dalsnibba and it is easy to find as it is directly on the main road.

title: Expensive, but an old world charm with modern amenities
text: One of the nicer hotels in Norway. We were only there one night but wish it was longer. The smorgasbord is spectacular. We were lucky enough to get a room upgrade that gave us a fjord view and balcony. The rooms was large by European standards. There are free rowboats for guests if you are up to a little exercise to burn off all that food you are likely to eat.

title: Not spectacular but an easy short walk with views
text: This is about a mile in length with minor elevation gain. There are nicely situated benches for rests and views. You might need this if you are staying at the Kviknes and enjoying the Smorgasbord!

title: Guided Taxi Tour of Flam/Gudvangen Area
text: We wanted to avoid a crowded bus tour and get some expert local commentary so we took a chance on this taxi service. For a fixed price they will bring you to the local attractions. We were picked up at the Fretheim in Flam and our driver drove the snow road to the Stegastein Lookout and then to the Borgund Stave Church. Our driver, Roger, was tremendous. He is a local so he provides a fascinating running commentary as the trip unfolds. He is personable, speaks good English and drives safely on the twit roads. Had we driven or taken a bus we never would have learned all the interesting fats that Roger provided.

title: A Highlight of our Norway Trip
text: We are seniors and were a little reluctant to go kayaking as we weren't experienced and the thought was a little scary. But our concerns were quickly laid to rest when we arrived. Our guide, Antonio, was tremendous. He was patient and didn't mind our slow approach to the outing. He took the time to carefully go ver the entire process with us. When we finally got out in the water we had a tremendous time. We had a two man kayak and the front seat passenger doesn't even need to do anything if they so choose. The person in back does the steering. We took the short two hour tour and made it as far as the Seven Sisters waterfall. The pictures we got were great. Antonio even took our camera and took pictures and videos of us. Highly recommended.

title: Worth the trip
text: We also visited the Briksdalbreen glacier but this one is better. You can get much closer and this one is less visited. Along the way there is a fascinating historic marker to a tragic landslide that claimed many lives. New sure to stop and read the information there. The beauty of this glacier is the drive along Lovatnet Lake.

title: A bit disappointing
text: We visited this glacier and the nearby Kjenndalsbreen Glacier. We much preferred the latter. This glacier is much farther away from the parking lot. In fact you either need to walk a mile or so or pay for a train to bring you there. Also this one is loaded with tour buses. Best part of this for me was the drive past Lovatnet Lake.

title: Lotsa places to eat!
text: We stayed right on the River Walk at the Hyatt so we could literally walk the walk by stepping out of our hotel. The walk is interesting from a culinary point of view as there are countless places to eat and drink. Some fine dining and some fast food is available for all tastes. It is great for people watching. Little boats constantly traverse the river of those so inclined. Frankly, for me after one roundtrip of the downtown section I was done with it.

title: It's in your history books so you gotta see it
text: We could actually see it from our hotel room so it was interesting to see it around the clock. We had walked the Mission Walk farther south and frankly, this was the least interesting of the missions we saw. Other than the important history of what transpired at the Alamo it isn't much to see.

title: Great for a walk or bike trip!
text: The San Antonio Missions National Historical Park is now a UNESCO World Heritage site. Even if you don't care too much about the history it is a perfect way to spend a few hours walking or bicycling between the missions. There is a wide paved walk between the missions on both sides of the river. There are also bike rentals at each mission. We drove to the Visitor Center at Mission San José, parked our car and walked south along the river. By the time we reached Mission San Juan we were ready to bicycle so we rented bikes from the self service bike stands that dot the parkway. They're even listed on the Park Service maps.

title: Worth a visit
text:
I'm a lover of Presidential libraries and this one didn't disappoint. You can't help but get a different impression of LBJ after visiting.

Given the legislation he signed while President (Medicare, Medicaid, HeadStart, Vista, funding to establish PBS & NPR) he would be considered a Socialist today. (And let's not forget the Civil Rights and Voting Rights Acts.) His Presidency might be the peak of modern liberalism in our lifetimes.

Of course, there was Vietnam. The war was dealt with frankly and effectively. As a college student during that period I had learned to dislike LBJ due to the war. I still can't forgive him but after the visit I have softened my tone as I realize that he was as much a victim of history as he was a initiator of the conflict.
